data.text:
Emir Kusturica is a world-renowned director of Serbian descent, known for his unique style and provocative artistic vision. Born on November 24, 1954 in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kusturica was exposed to the world of cinema from a young age thanks to his father, a film journalist. After studying cinema at the University of Arts in Belgrade, Kusturica began his career making documentaries before directing his first feature film, “Your voice follows me” in 1981, which immediately achieved great success.

His fame grew rapidly with films such as “Dad is on a Business Trip” (Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival in 1985) and “Black Cat, White Cat” (Best Director Award at Venice in 1998). Kusturica is also known for his talents as a musician, and he has often incorporated his passion for music into his films, creating a deep connection between the two art forms. His international fame is the result of undeniable talent and a bold artistic vision.

Emir Kusturica is one of the most acclaimed and recognized European directors, also a musician and writer. Born in 1954 in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kusturica is best known for his unique style and his talent for telling authentic, often surreal stories rooted in the social and political reality of the Balkans. His films, such as “Dad is on a Business Trip” (1985), “Underground” (1995) and “Life is a Miracle” (2004), are famous for their captivating aesthetics, eccentric characters and storylines. originals that tackle themes such as war, family, love and identity.

Kusturica has won numerous prestigious awards, including the Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival twice, cementing his reputation as a talented author on an international level. He also made documentaries and short films, showing his interest in social issues and Balkan folklore. Alongside his film career, Kusturica is passionate about music, particularly Balkan music. He formed his own band, “The No Smoking Orchestra”, with which he recorded several albums and performed concerts around the world. This passion is also reflected in his films, where music often plays a central role. Emir Kusturica is a versatile and committed artist, whose work has marked European cinema with its originality, its poetry and its engaged view of society.

Emir Kusturica is a famous filmmaker of Yugoslav origin. Born on November 24, 1954 in Sarajevo, Bosnia-Herzegovina, he comes from a family of artists and intellectuals. His father, Murat Kusturica, is a writer and politician, while his mother, Senka Numankadić, is an actress and documentary film director. Emir’s interest in cinema undoubtedly comes from his family environment. On his father’s side, Emir Kusturica’s genealogy goes back to his grandmother, Milica Vojinović, who was also a theater and film actress. His grandfather, Džemal Kusturica, was a prominent writer and poet. The family lineage continues with his great-grandfather, Husein Kusturica, an accomplished playwright and his great-great-grandfather on his father’s side, Ali Young Pedija, was a well-respected poet in the region.

On his mother’s side, Emir Kusturica is the grandson of Numankadić Irfan, himself a well-known intellectual in Yugoslav artistic circles. Her maternal grandmother, Meftuneh Numankadić, was also known for her engagement in arts and culture. This rich family lineage therefore marked the childhood and artistic career of Emir Kusturica, passing on to him a taste for cinema and art in general. Thus, thanks to the influences of his ancestors, Emir Kusturica became one of the most renowned and prolific directors of his time, notably winning two Palmes d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival for his films “Papa is on a business trip” (1985) and “Underground” (1995).
